title: An Honest Neighborhood Eatery
text: You may want to try our neighborhood favorite tavern/restaurant called "Opos Palia" (like in the old days) offering a wide variety of local dishes, cooked like a Greek grandma would do, in generous portions and modest prices, close to the Acropolis Museum. Highly recommended!

title: A Fine Restaurant with a Great View
text: For a fine meal, or a drink, with a spectacular view of the Acropolis and the Acropolis Museum, you may try Balcony. Modern Greek cuisine of high standards, superb service, wonderful atmosphere, for a special night out.

title: A rocky hill overlooking Athens
text: Mount Lycabettus, or rather the Hill of Lycabettus, is a rocky hill of limestone at 300 meters above sea level, overlooking Athens. Pine trees cover the foothills, and the 19th c. Chapel of St. George, is built atop. An open-air theatre hosts mostly music events, and a restaurant, offers stupendous night views of the city. A funicular railway can take you to the top of the hill, unless you are fit enough to use the steps...

title: An excellent break for a snack or a refreshment!
text: I have been to Antonis Cafe several times. It is an excellent pit stop ahead of visiting historic Plaka or busy Syntagma, for a snack (try his legendary hot dog), a refreshment or something more substantial. Friendly atmosphere, excellent service, value prices, no-nonsense decor, and an enticing menu will persuade you to become a regular visitor, such as I!

title: The most important monument of the Free World!
text: Acropolis, is a rocky hill, standing in the center of Athens, hosting a complex of magnificent buildings, including the Parthenon, most built at 500 BC, as a tribute to democracy and the triumph of free-thinking men, creating democracy, the arts, and the foundations of science. It is a must-visit for all who are able to travel, as a personal pilgrimage to where it all started from!

title: An Impressive Archaeological Site
text: Just 5 km from the town of Pythagoreion, the visitor may see one of the very few, and certainly the most impressive sanctuaries of the ancient Greek world built to honor Hera, the sister/wife of Zeus. In a serene setting, at sea level, of colossal size, the main temple was surrounded by several other smaller temples and administrative structures, testifying to the huge importance of the site in those times. A must visit! (The beach a few hundred yards away is excellent for a refreshing swim!)

title: Samos is a Wonderful Island
text: Samos is a wonderful island. Large enough to give you plenty to see and experience, small enough for you to have the time to leisurely do it. Plenty of fantastic beaches to swim in the cool waters, archaeological sites to connect with the island's long history, modern and traditional pottery and other artifacts, many eateries to taste the local cuisine, excellent local wines, and mostly warm nice people. Olive groves, grapevines, fig trees, cypress trees and pines are abound, and a northeastern breeze cools down the heat of the Summer. We jest returned from a family vacation, and I would gladly return!

title: Good Food at a Nice spot
text: The food was good, the setting was nice, right next to a natural water spring, the people were courteous, the service was unusually slow. Mid-August is indeed a high season, max traffic time of the year, and this alone should not be a deterrent to a visit.

title: Very nice Greek Cuisine
text: We had a family lunch on a leisurely day at Almyriki. The service was great, the food excellent, the prices were right and we enjoyed every minute. Recommended!

title: Good Food at a Good Value
text: The tavern is by the sea, on a wonderful beach, and offers very good food, mostly seafood but not only, at good prices. Worth a visit!

title: A descent Greek restaurant by the sea
text: Remataki is a good restaurant offering descent Greek cuisine on an excellent setting by the sea, though a bit "touristy" for our taste, including live Greek music.

title: An Excellent Choice for Greek Cuisine
text: At the outskirts of the village of Manolates, just 4 km off the seaside Agios Konstantinos, the visitor will encounter a traditional village home, turned into a tavern, where Manolis, the proprietor, and original founder's son, offers excellent traditional Greek cuisine made of local, mostly self-produced ingredients, and his own home--made wine. A must-visit when in Samos!

title: Excellent Greek Food by the Sea
text: A family restaurant by the sea, offering excellent traditional Greek cuisine at great value and with a friendly and warm service.

title: A Serene Place to Base Your Vacations in Samos
text: Beautifully appointed in the Kokkari area, but away from the touristic buzz, this well-kept family property boasts a magnificent view of the Aegean Sea, through fifteen or so studio units that are spacious, fully equipped, fully Air-Conditioned, sparkling clean, run by courteous owners, and a short walk or an even shorter drive from a multitude of fantastic beaches!

title: A Great Place to Relax
text: Beautifully appointed by the Kokkari seaside, Cavos offers a multitude of options to enjoy and relax, including 2-3 giant TV screens for viewing great soccer or basketball games.

title: Best ice cream in Kokkari!
text: The place offers a multitude of choices. Our son had a club sandwich, our daughter a waffle with ice cream, my wife had ekmec with kaimaki ice cream and I had an applepie with ice cream. All excellent! Bravo Manolis!

title: Best drinks and desserts in town!
text: We visited twice, all four of us, and enjoyed some wonderful desserts, snacks, along with superbly chosen quality rock music and a talented bartender.

title: An honest Greek family restaurant by the sea
text: We had lunch, twice, at this seaside restaurant and were captivated by the unassuming quality of the food, prepared mostly using treasures from the family grove, but also of the service and kindness of the hostess. Try the home wine!

title: The earliest theater in the world!
text: Theater of Dionysus is the most ancient theater of the world. The most important ancient Greek poets, Aeschylus, Aristophanes, Euripides, and Sophocles saw premiere performances of their plays in the 5th century BC, right here, at the foothills of the Acropolis. The theater was dedicated to Dionysus, the god of wine and the patron of drama. The theater even hosted, on occasion. meetings of the Athenian Ekklesia (parliament) after the original Pnyx site was deemed unsuitable.

title: Very Good to Have in our Neighborhood
text: Greeks stay up late at night. Coming back home to an empty fridge, or too tired to cook even something easy, it is a great comfort to have To 24oro open 24-hours a day, with a wide variety of dishes of all sorts, ready to serve and at very reasonable price. Strategically located in a tourist area, it is highly reccommended!

title: Decent Homey Greek Food in a Friendly Environment
text: We have gone three times in one month for a family lunch. Each and every time, the food was excellent, the portions generous, the choices ample, the prices extremely reasonable and the service friendly and polite. Not surprisingly, the restaurant is packed with happy customers, both locals and visitors!

title: An Excellent Wine Bar near the Acropolis Museum
text: Winepoint is an excellent low-key yet high-quality wine bar in the neighborhood of the Acropolis Museum, offering a wide selection of carefully chosen Greek wines. Try them with a cheese platter and delve into the divine delight of true pleasure!

title: A world-class Museum
text: The Greek National Archaeological Museum in Athens with an extensive collection of artworks from the various archaeological areas of Greece, covering the whole wide range from prehistoric to late historic periods of history is one of the finest museums of the world.

title: Excellent traditional Greek food
text: A tiny unassuming place, on Voulis Street, offering excellent traditional Greek food from casserole to seafood. Highly recommended for families, couples or just yourself. Not for groups due t lack of space.

title: Excellent choice for Greek cuisine
text: A wonderful relatively small restaurant serving excellent Greek traditional cuisine to a loyal clientele and happy newcomers.

title: A popular traditional Greek restaurant
text: More than decent traditional Greek cuisine suitable for both families, groups of friends or couples. Wide menu, good service, nice atmosphere!

title: A true French Bistrot in the heart of Athens
text: Chez Lucien is a low-key cozy French bistrot in Ano Petralona district of Athens, serving excellent food in decent prices. I highly recommend it!

title: A Cultural Oasis
text: Little Tree is a cultural oasis on the crossroads of the Acropolis, Makriyanni and Koukaki neighborhoods of Athens, offering fine coffee, tasteful desserts, and delicious treats, in an unassuming bistrot-like setting, with hundreds of books to read and buy. Strongly recommended!

title: The finest bakery
text: Takis Bakery is by far the finest bakery in town, at the foothills of the Acropolis, offering all sorts of breads, pies, cakes, sandwiches, everything one would seek in a first-class European bakery!

title: A Poor Excuse of a Beach Bar
text: We went there at about 10 pm. It was a holiday and the two other places on the beach had traditional live Greek music. We sat on the side of the street that looks toward the sea. For over twenty minutes nobody cared to wait on us. My wife crossed the street and found the waitress. Finally, another twenty minutes later she came to tell us that the ice-cream fridge was out of order, there was no fresh juice, the coffee machine was switched off for the day and the only things available were alcoholic drinks. I am surprised this establishment still exists.

title: Fair Mediterranean Food
text: Located on Meloi Beach, Patmos, the restaurant features a fair menu of Greek Food at fair prices in relatively small portions. Good choice if you are already on the beach but nothing exceptional to go there for food alone.

title: A Fine Cafe at Scala
text: A fine establishment in the heart of Scala, nicely situated, tastefully decorated with friendly personnel, a wide choice of coffee, ouzo, meze, dessert and drinks, and music with an attitude.

title: Mediterranean Taste
text: A fine Mediterranean fusion cuisine in a nice garden setting, offering good service and fine tastes.

title: One of the Best Beaches in Patmos
text: Lampi Beach is certainly one of the best beaches in Patmos. Even though it has a Northern orientation and gets to have high waves mid-August, it is wide, has clean waters, and a rare sort of sparkling pebbles, where it takes its name from. We recommend it!

title: A first-class restaurant atop Chora!
text: My family and I enjoyed a first-class dinner at Jimmy's Balcony. The service was excellent, the food was delicious, the house wine was delightful and Jimmy himself a real treat! Highly recommended!

title: Seaside delight
text: A small seaside restaurant at Alinda, Leros, offering excellent seafood and not only. My wife and I had calamari and fried zucchini balls, our children had grilled chicken breast and spaghetti bolognese, we shared boiled greens and french fries. All was delicious and highly recommended!

title: A seaside restaurant at Alinda, Leros
text: Very professional, offering good food, good service and fair prices, this restaurant is always full with people enjoying the food, a sure indication of success. Everything we ate was tasty and we enjoyed it!

title: A well-organized beach in the quaint island of Leros
text: Though I am not a proponent of organized beaches and prefer quiet, less frequented spots, this picturesque beach with ample natural beauty is professionally-run and preferred by many younger people. Offers refreshments, coffee and drinks, umbrellas, recliners, etc.

title: A Greek Island Port with an Italian Flavor
text: Lakki Port is a very deep,naturally formed, port serving the island of Leros, where the ferry boat and all commercial traffic, but also pleasure boats of all sizes are professionally served. The port is surrounded by a number of public buildings mostly created during the era of the Italian rule of the island, along with all sorts of cafes, restaurants and shops.

title: A wonderful retreat in Leros
text: The two of us and both of our children had a memorable vacation in this wonderful hotel in Alinda, the island of Leros, in the Aegean Archipelagos. Spacious, clean, fully-equipped rooms, all with balconies, wonderful settings, complete with the neighboring citrus fruit orchard and spectacular views, offering swimming pools for children and adults, a low-key full-service poolside bar, a hearty and healthy buffet for breakfast, gracious staff. A short walk to two different beaches and several seaside restaurants and cafes, but also to a full-scale supermarket, traditional bakery, a kiosk, etc.

title: A superb beach, if you like cold waters
text: We went for a swim in Gournes Beach three times. Spectacular long sandy beach, sparkling clean cold waters, ideal for younger children, pleasant for all.

title: A spectacular secluded small beach
text: You have to go by car, but this is a spectacular small beach, ideal for families or couples, with great waters and views!

title: A pleasant long beach worth visiting
text: Alindas Beach is a pleasant long seaside walk, offering several spots perfect for swimming, but also a selection of restaurants and cafes, shops, car rental agencies, etc.

title: Excellent pizza by the sea
text: Excellent, home-style, wood-oven-baked pizza, offering great value for the money, in a small courtyard by the sea, or to take away or delivery.

title: Great Greek traditional seafood by the sea
text: We had a wonderful selection of basic lunch staples, including marida small fried fish, vleta greens, french fries, tomatokeftedes (tomato fried balls), and some local wine. All were excellent.

title: A quiet family beach in Leros
text: Spectacular, long sandy beach, sparkling clean, relatively cold waters, slowly slopping depth ideal for younger children, tree shade, parking area, pleasant for all

title: A Byzantine monument in the center of a commercial street
text: On Ermou Street, the most prominent commercial street of Athensl, there is one of the most important monuments of Byzantine architecture, the church dedicated to the Presentation of Virgin Mary, known as Panaghia Kapnikarea, built at the beginning of the 11th century on the ruins of an ancient temple, dedicated either to the goddess Athena or to Demeter.

title: Zappeion Hall, in the heart of Athens.
text: Located in the center of Athens, Zappeion Hall is the preeminent venue for domestic and international events in Athens, within a short walking distance from the Panathenaic Stadium of the 1896 Olympic Games, and Syntagma Square, surrounded by over 200,000 square meters of gardens with meandering paths, fountains and over 70 works of sculpture.

title: Tasty Traditional Greek Cuisine
text: Over the years I have been to this restaurant several times, and was always satisfied from both the food itself and the service. Fairly priced, with generous portions and no frills homey recipes of traditional Greek cuisine.

title: View, Food and Service Fit for VIPs
text: It has been some time now since we last had dinner at Strofi, but from what I know it continues to be an excellent choice. Superb views of the Acropolis, courteous service, very friendly towards our children, big portions, tasty Greek cuisine.

title: Athens Top Rated Bakery, by the locals
text: Takis happens to be my neighborhood bakery. Locals and visitors alike flock to taste the numerous baked goods, from a wide variety of breads, to tarts and cakes, cookies, baked sweets, fresh sandwiches, cheese pies, koulouri Greek "pretzels", etc.etc.

title: Unexpected Respite!
text: From sunrise to sunset the National Gardens, originally the Royal Gardens, provide a peaceful respite from the busy life of Athens and a natural life reserve for both flora and fauna. It also encloses a number of ancient ruins, but also public sculpture, a duck pond, a Botanical Museum, a small cafe, and a children's playground.

title: Panaghia Gorgoepikoos: A Temple of All Ages
text: Next to the Metropolitan Cathedral, at Metropoleos Sq., is the elegant, small church of Panaghia Gorgoepikoos (the one quick to hear), aka Aghios Eleftherios, built in the 13th c. over an ancient temple dedicated to the goddess Eileithyia. The church was entirely constructed with the ruins of ancient temples and votive offerings, to which time has given a wonderful patina. The walls of the church are made of large, ancient Greek, Roman and early Byzantine marble blocks and relief plaques, without bricks.

title: Hadrian's Arch marks the boundary between the ancient and the Roman parts of Athens
text: On the road from the Acropolis to the Temple of Olympian Zeus, a two-story triumphal arch of white marble was erected in 131-132 A.D., in honor of Roman Emperor Hadrian, a benefactor of the city of Athens, marking the boundary between the old city of Athens and the new city constructed mostly during his rule and bearing his name.

title: Monastiraki Old Market of Athens
text: Monastiraki, (little monastery) has narrow streets and small buildings. Here is the flea market neighborhood in the old quarters of the city of Athens and one of the principal shopping districts in Athens. On the outdoor stands of street vendors, or the small shops on the central roads, the area is home to several clothing boutiques, souvenir shops, and specialty stores, and is a major tourist attraction for bargain shopping since you can find anything, such as shoes and leather sandals, traditional clothes or hip garments, used or new furniture, old books and maps, antiques and curiosities.

title: The magnificent Temple of Olympian Zeus in Athens
text: The most magnificent monument in Athens, other than the Acropolis complex of sites, is the Temple of the Olympian Zeus. In 1312 AD, in a grand ceremony, Roman Emperor Hadrian inaugurated the temple, the construction of which had begun in the 6th century BC. The gigantic temple of the Corinthian order was twice the size of the Parthenon and its interior housed a splendid statue of Zeus.

title: An old-fashioned bar in a historic neighborhood
text: Within the historic Acropolis-Makriyanni neighborhood, you may find this small old-fashioned bistro-bar for a drink or two and an optional wonderful dinner to go along.

title: An excellent take-away grill
text: This is a small take-away grill, serving Constantinople-style high-quality affordable street food like kebab and souvlaki on Dionyssiou Areopagitou, the most magnificent pedestrian street near the Acropolis.

title: The Temple of Hephaestus once thought to be of Thesseus
text: This impressive temple within the Athenian Agora site is almost intact and presents a perfect example of a doric peripheral hexastyle building of the most glorious era of ancient Athens. It is rising on a plateau with three steps. The length of the temple is 31 m. (104 ft.) by 13 m. (45 1/2") and its height is 10 m. (34 ft.). From a distance it looks larger than it actually is, with its curves and inclination of the columns towards the center and with a splendid patina of the weather-stained white marble from the quarries of Mt. Penteli.

title: Syntagma Square, the Center of Athens
text: Syntagma Square is not an attraction itself, it is however where the Greek Parliament building is, the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, guarded by the Evzones traditional guards, the high-end central Hotel Row, as well as the one end of Ermou Street, the busiest commercial street in Athens. This is where all political rallies start from or end, and this is the city center from which distances to Athens are measured from!
